Pleasant48859MichiganUSAgrid.264756.40000000446872082Department of ChemistryTexas A&M UniversityCollege Station77843TexasUSAp.squattrito@cmich.edu7620068200636848750120122005296200520122005762006© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 20062006

Salts of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate with divalent Mg, Mn, Co, and Ni cations have been crystallized and their structures determined by single crystal X-ray methods. The Mg, Mn, and Co salts are isostructural. Crystal data for hexaaquamagnesium(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Mg(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.1329(18) Å, b=8.5789(11) Å, c=12.4880(17) Å, β=93.374(3)°, V=1511.5(3) Å3; hexaaquamanganese(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.249(3) Å, b=8.5940(17) Å, c=12.505(3) Å, β=93.30(3)°, V=1528.8(6) Å3; hexaaquacobalt(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.1406(18) Å, b=8.5674(11) Å, c=12.4960(16) Å, β=93.297(2)°, V=1511.4(3) Å3. The structures are composed of alternating layers of octahedral metal–aqua complexes and sulfonate anions linked by hydrogen bonds. The three water molecules of crystallization are associated with the hexaaquametal cations and sulfonate O atoms. The repeat unit along the a-axis is a single layer. The Ni salt [crystal data for tetraaquabis(5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonato-N)nickel(II) dihydrate, [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]·2H2O: triclinic, \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$P\bar 1$$\end{document}, Z=1, a=6.8524(10) Å, b=8.3094(12) Å, c=11.4832(17) Å, α=69.003(2)°, β=76.570(3)°, γ=83.952(2)°, V=593.56(15) Å3] has a very different structure with direct coordination of the amine N atom to Ni, a modified stacking pattern, and fewer free water molecules. Ag and Ni salts of an amine-substituted naphthalenedisulfonate have also been characterized. Crystal data for diaqua(6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonato-O)silver(I) hydrate,

[Ag(H2O)2(H3NC10H5(SO3)2)]·0.42H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=9.099(3) Å, b=21.406(6) Å, c=7.629(2) Å, β=110.178(4)°, V=1394.9(7) Å3; tetraaquabis (6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonato-O)nickel(II)tetrahydrate, [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H5 (SO3)2)2]·4H2O: triclinic,\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$P\bar 1$$\end{document}, Z=1, a=6.7971(17) Å, b=10.661(3) Å, c=11.165(3) Å, α=68.308(4)°, β=88.292(5)°, γ=84.896(5)°, V=748.8(3) Å3. The silver salt contains six coordinate metal centers each of which bonds to four sulfonate O atoms from three different anions and two water molecules. The nickel salt contains octahedral cations with four water molecules and two trans sulfonate O atoms. Both structures are layered, but differently from each other and from those of the monofunctional naphthalenesulfonate salts.

Unusual coordination of a sulfonate group to a transition metal and coordination of an amine group to nickel but not to cobalt or manganese have been observed in a series of metal aminonaphthalenesulfonate salts

Introduction

Compounds with structures composed of alternating inorganic and organic domains have been of interest over the past two decades for their potential to act as host structures for various chemical processes.1,2 Among the most widely studied have been metal organophosphonate salts of the general formula Mm(O3PR)n·xH2O in which R is an aliphatic or aromatic organic group. The oxygen atoms of the phosphonate group coordinate to the metal ion, sometimes along with some water molecules. Most commonly, a two-dimensional metal–oxygen–phosphorus framework is formed, though chain and three-dimensional structures are also known.3-8 In all these materials, the R groups act as spacers between the inorganic parts. The resulting structures have rigid covalent inorganic frameworks separated by weakly interacting organic moieties. The use of different organic groups alters the size and nature of the organic region, and hence the physical properties of the material. More recently, we and others have explored the structural chemistry of analogous organosulfonate salts Mm(O3SR)n·xH2O and have found both similarities to and differences from the corresponding phosphonates. Particular attention has been focused on various arenesulfonates, including benzene9–13 and naphthalene14–21 derivatives. As an extension of these studies, we have synthesized and structurally characterized four salts of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and two salts of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid in order to compare the coordination behaviors and packing patterns to those of related naphthalenesulfonates with different substitution patterns (Scheme 1).

ExperimentalSyntheses and thermal analyses

Mg(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O. A 1.500 g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid (Aldrich, >95%) was mixed with a 0.186 g (3.2 mmol) sample of magnesium hydroxide (Amend Drug & Chemical) in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 15 min. The resulting clear maroon solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm) pale mauve diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (this and subsequent reactions were repeated three times: average yield 1.06 g, 48%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the crystals performed from 50 to 800°C at a 20°C/min gradient shows two distinct mass losses centered at roughly 333 and 408 K each corresponding to loss of six molecules of water per formula unit. Presumably, the first six are the waters of crystallization while the second six are those coordinated to the Mg cation. The resulting anhydrous metal sulfonate is stable up to ca. 773 K where a further mass loss (∼16%) occurs as decomposition of the organic commences.

Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O. A 1.500g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid was combined with 0.366 g (3.2 mmol) of manganese(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) in 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 1 h. The resulting clear dark purple solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm), pale violet diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (average yield 0.76 g, 33%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. TGA of the crystals shows a split mass loss centered at 346 and 387 K, less well resolved than that of the Mg compound. The total mass loss of ∼29.5% that is complete at 502 K corresponds to loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit (theoretical 30.2%). The anhydrous sulfonate salt is stable to further mass loss up to approximately 775 K.

[Co(H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O)<sub><italic>6</italic></sub>](H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>NC<sub><italic>10</italic></sub>H<sub><italic>6</italic></sub>SO<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>·6H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O

The synthesis of this compound was carried out similarly to that of the Mg compound, using 0.311 g (3.3 mmol) of cobalt(II) hydroxide (Aldrich, tech. 95%) and 1.502 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid. The resulting dark purple solution was gravity-filtered and set out at room temperature in an open container. After the solvent had evaporated, numerous large (up to 4 mm in diameter) red purple plate-like, diamond-shaped crystals of the product (average yield 1.69 g, 71%) were separated manually from the polycrystalline residue. In the TGA of the crystals, there were two distinct and roughly equal mass losses centered at 332 and 405 K. The total mass loss of about 31% that is complete by 435 K is consistent with loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit. Subsequent decomposition of the anhydrous material, as indicated by renewed mass loss (∼29%), begins at roughly 805 K.

[Ni(H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O)<sub><italic>4</italic></sub> (H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>NC<sub><italic>10</italic></sub>H<sub><italic>6</italic></sub> SO<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>] · <italic>2</italic>H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O

This compound was prepared according to the same procedure as the Mn compound, using 1.503 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and 0.375 g (3.2 mmol) of nickel(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent). An average of 1.58 g of dark purple diamond-shaped plates were collected for an 82% yield based on Ni. The TGA of these crystals showed a continuous mass loss of ∼19% complete by 392 K. This mass loss is slightly above the 17.7% loss expected for six molecules of H2O and is most likely due to some additional hydration of the crystals that may have occurred on standing. The similarity in crystal morphology to the Mg, Mn, and Co compounds suggests that the Ni compound should be isomorphous, however the color (purple) is consistent with the coordination environment of the Ni as determined by the X-ray analysis. As for the other compounds in this series, the anhydrous metal sulfonate shows good thermal stability and does not begin to decompose to volatile products until about 810 K.

[Ag (H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub> (H<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>NC<sub><italic>10</italic></sub>H<sub><italic>5</italic></sub> (SO<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>)] · <italic>0.42H</italic><sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O

A 1.504 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt (Eastman Organic Chemicals) and 1.464 g (8.6 mmol) of silver nitrate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting pale olive green solution was allowed to react for approximately 1 h, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Upon evaporation of most of the water, a thick mat of long pale yellow needle-shaped crystals was isolated from the bottom of the dish (average yield 2.27 g, >100% due to residual moisture in the product). TGA revealed a mass loss of approximately 7% complete by 375 K. This is somewhat less than the 9.6% expected based on the formula obtained from the X-ray structure. Given that the water of crystallization in this compound is present at partial occupancy, it is possible that the low water count obtained from the TGA is due to loss of water from the crystals prior to analysis. If only the coordinated water were retained in the structure, the expected mass loss on dehydration would be 8.1%. The rest of the TGA shows that this compound is less thermally stable than the others, with a series of significant mass losses beginning at 485 K. Unlike the divalent sulfonates, essentially the entire mass of the silver compound is ultimately volatilized by ∼890 K.

[Ni (H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O)<sub><italic>4</italic></sub> (H<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>NC<sub><italic>10</italic></sub>H<sub><italic>5</italic></sub> (SO<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>]· <italic>4</italic>H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O

A 1.500 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt and 1.255 g (4.3 mmol) of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Aldrich) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting green solution was stirred for 20 min, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Evaporation of the water yielded many long green needles of the product (average yield 0.86 g, 25%), which were recovered manually from the polycrystalline residue. TGA showed a ∼20% mass loss complete by 490 K that is somewhat higher than the 17.9% expected for loss of eight water molecules per formula unit. This discrepancy could be due to residual moisture in the sample. The dehydrated material is stable up to 630 K, where a large (∼35%) mass loss begins. Thus, both salts of the 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate are less thermally stable than the salts of the 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate.

Crystallographic studies

Data collections (1.4°< θ < 28.2°) were performed at 110, 273, or 293 K on a Bruker Smart CCD-1000 diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ=0.71073 Å) radiation and an OXFORD cool stream low-temperature control unit using liquid nitrogen gas as coolant. Data reduction, cell refinement, and multiscan absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT program.22 The cell parameters were indexed from reflections obtained from 60 frames with an exposure of 10 s/frame. Full-spheres of data (2400 frames at 5 cm detector distances) were collected by the narrow-frame method with frame widths of 0.03° in θ and exposure time of 20–30 s/frame. The first 50 frames were recorded at the end of data collection to assess the stability of the crystals, and the decay in intensity was found to be less than 1% in all cases. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXTL-9723) with atomic coordinates and anisotropic displacement parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms. For the silver 6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate structure, a peak corresponding to the oxygen atom of a disordered water molecule was refined with variable occupancy factor to arrive at the observed formula. Hydrogen atoms for this water molecule could not be located. All other hydrogen atoms were located on difference electron density maps and were refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Crystallographic data for the structures are provided in Tables 1–3. Structural diagrams were generated using the CrystalMaker24 program.

Results and discussion

The compounds [Mg(H2O)6] (H2NC10H6 SO3)2·6H2O, [Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O, and [Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O are isostructural. Their molecular structure is presented in Fig. 1, a packing diagram showing the unit cell is provided in Fig. 2, and a view onto a single anion layer is given in Fig. 3. The metal cation rests on an inversion center and is coordinated to six water molecules in a highly regular octahedron as indicated by the bond distances and angles in Tables 4 and 5. There is no direct metal coordination by the sulfonate oxygen atoms or amine N atom. The range of Mg–O, Mn–O, and Co–O distances (Table 4) are similar to those reported for other hexaaqua complexes of these cations.25,26 There are also three noncoordinating water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The sulfonate group is positioned as in other naphthalenesulfonates15,19 with one oxygen atom (O3) nearly eclipsing the ring. The bond distances and angles about the S atom are consistent with those seen in similar compounds, including the modest opening of the O–S–O angles and narrowing of the O–S–C angles from the ideal tetrahedral value.

The extended structure shows layers (parallel to the b–c plane) of anions alternating with layers of cations (Fig. 2), which is the typical motif for divalent sulfonate salts.20 Each anion layer contains pairs of cofacial naphthalene rings related by centers of inversion (Fig. 3) so that the SO3− and NH2 groups are directed to opposite sides of the layer in an alternating fashion in the c-direction. Anions with the same orientation repeat to form rows that extend along b. Anions related by the inversion center at z=1/2 are canted approximately 108° with respect to those centered about the symmetry elements at z=0 (Fig. 3). This type of staggered herringbone arrangement has been observed previously in the nickel and cobalt salts of 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate.19 The layers are held together by a strong network of approximately linear O–H⋯O and N–H⋯O hydrogen bonds involving the amino, water, and sulfonate groups. Two of the three free water molecules per formula unit are located in between the metal complexes in the inorganic layer, while the third is associated with the sulfonate group. The layers are arranged such that the repeat unit in the stacking direction consists of a single inorganic–organic layer. This structural motif is somewhat unusual for metal arene-monosulfonate salts, which mostly form double-layer repeat structures (i.e., inorganic–organic–inorganic–organic).14,15,19 The cell length along the stacking direction a of ∼14.2 Å, representing the thickness of a single inorganic–organic slab, is greater than the ∼11.6 Å observed for the Mg and Mn salts of 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate19 and the ∼13.5 Å found in alkali metal salts of 6-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate.14 These differences represent the change in orientation of the naphthalene ring system with respect to the stacking direction. In all cases, the anions pack with the polar/charged groups (NH2 and SO3−) on the surfaces of the layer where interactions with cations and water are maximized. The 4,1 isomer has these groups para to each other on the same ring, so that the anions are arranged with the long direction of the naphthalene ring system approximately parallel to the layer. The 5,2 isomer has the long direction of the ring system much closer to perpendicular to the layer rather than parallel. The 6,2 isomer, in which the polar groups are as far apart as possible, stacks with the long direction of the ring system nearly perpendicular to the layer. The reason the intralayer distance is not longer for these salts is that the alkali metals bond directly to the sulfonate oxygen atoms. Presumably, hexaaquametal salts of the 6,2 anion would in fact have the thickest slabs among these isomers. This behavior demonstrates that the nature and arrangement of substituent groups on arenesulfonates is an important factor in determining the exact structure adopted by salts of these anions with given metal ions.

Surprisingly, the nickel salt of this sulfonate, [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]·2H2O, is different in both formula and structure from the Mg, Mn, and Co compounds. The molecular structure is shown in Fig. 4 and the packing structure is depicted in Fig. 5. The nickel cation is octahedrally coordinated by four water molecules and two amino N atoms on the sulfonate anions. The N atoms are trans as required by the inversion symmetry of the Ni site. The coordination of the amino group, while unmistakable from the crystal structure, is also indicated by the purple color of the crystals which is indicative of octahedral Ni(II) in a nitrogen ligand environment. That direct coordination of the amino group occurs for Ni only in this series may reflect the greater affinity of nickel(II) for N donors compared to the other divalent cations. The stepwise and overall formation constants for [Ni(NH3)1–6]2+ are all greater than the corresponding values for Co2+, and of course much greater than those of Mn2+ or Mg2+.27 Nevertheless, in our previous study of the 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate isomer, the Mg, Mn, Co, and Ni salts all contained fully aquated metal ions.19 Another amino-substituted sulfonate that has been widely studied with divalent transition metals is the sulfanilate anion (para-aminobenzenesulfonate), for which the Mg,25 Mn,28 and Co29 salts have been reported. All have different structures. In the sulfanilate structures, direct metal coordination occurs to the sulfonate O atoms and amino N atoms for Mn and Co while not for Mg, which is fully hydrated. A simple Ni sulfanilate salt has not been reported, however, a diaquabis(1,3-propanediamine)nickel(II) sulfanilate compound shows no direct coordination between the nickel ion and the sulfanilate anion.30 By contrast, Mn and Co salts of 2-aminotoluene-4-sulfonate31 are both fully hydrated (no amine or sulfonate coordination), while the Ni salt has not been characterized. Clearly, additional studies are needed to establish the extent to which nickel is unique in these systems.

The extended structure of [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]·2H2O shows the familiar arrangement of alternating layers of cations and anions, in this case parallel to the a–b plane and stacking along c. The anions are again packing with the SO3− and NH2 groups on adjacent anions in opposite up and down orientations. The sulfonate group is positioned somewhat differently with respect to the ring system, as indicated by the ∼27° O3–S1–C2–C3 torsion angle (Table 5). As was the case with the Mg, Mn, and Co salts, the repeat unit is a single layer, though the repeat distance along c (∼11.5 Å) is much shorter in the Ni compound since the anion layers are linked directly to the cations through the amino group. Perhaps for this same reason, there are only one-third as many free water molecules in this structure: two water molecules of crystallization per formula unit or one per asymmetric unit, found in the cation layer. The more compact packing is reflected in the greater density of the Ni salt compared to the Co salt (Table 2).

Two new structures of a naphthalenedisulfonate have also been determined. The molecular structure of [Ag(H2O)2 (H3NC10H5(SO3)2)]·0.42H2O is presented in Fig. 6, while two views of the extended structure are shown in Figs. 7 and 8. The compound crystallized with one silver(I) cation, one protonated 6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate anion, two coordinated water molecules, and one water molecule of crystallization at partial (∼42%) occupancy in the asymmetric unit. The silver ion is in a distorted sixfold coordination of four sulfonate O atoms from three different anions and two water molecules. According to the bond distances (Table 4), there are four closer interactions with Ag–O distances in the typical range for silver sulfonates21,32 and two somewhat more distant (but nevertheless significant) interactions. Direct coordination of sulfonate groups to monovalent cations with only moderate amounts of water present is a common characteristic of silver21 and alkali metal9,14 sulfonate salts. Cote and Shimizu21 have postulated that arenesulfonates below a certain width will form salts with silver in which the layers contain an (–Ag–O–S–) network with no water, while larger aryl groups will prevent the necessary compactness of such structures, with the result that water is included to supplement the coordination of the metal. Although his analysis was limited to monosulfonates without other substituents, the protonation of the amino group in our case renders the stoichiometry the same. Thus, it seems fair to conclude that the steric demands of the 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate are sufficient to preclude the formation of an anhydrous coordination network. The absence of direct coordination to the amino group is contrary to what is found in silver sulfanilate.33

Of the coordinated sulfonate anions, two are monodentate, through O1 and O2 [generated by inversion center at (1/2 1 1/2)], while the third is bidentate through O5 and O6 [generated by inversion center at (0 1 0)]. Two oxygen atoms on each sulfonate group bond to a silver ion, while one does not. Of the O atoms that do not interact with Ag, one (O4) has a noticeably short S–O bond length while the other (O3) does not. The sulfonate groups are arranged with one O atom approximately eclipsing the naphthalene ring. As shown in Fig. 6, the silver ions bridge the sulfonate anions in such a way as to create dimeric units with 16-membered rings of two Ag, four O, four S, and six C atoms. These units are not isolated, but rather linked in a three-dimensional network via the connections to other anions through O2. The resulting extended structure is layered, with silver ions just off the a–c plane in a slightly ruffled array alternating with the anions. The anions are arranged so that the naphthalene rings are approximately parallel (Fig. 7), but adjacent anions along c have their rings tilted in the opposite directions with respect to the stacking direction (Fig. 8). The repeat unit is a double layer, with silver layers centered at y=0 and 1/2 and anion layers at y=1/4 and 3/4. The b-axis length indicates a layer thickness of ∼11.7 Å, reflecting the tilting of the rings as well as the direct bonding between the cations and anions.

The molecular structure of [Ni(H2O)4(H3NC10H5(SO3)2)2]·4H2O is depicted in Fig. 9, while a view of the packing is provided in Fig. 10. The nickel(II) ion is located on a center of inversion and is octahedrally coordinated by four water molecules and two sulfonate O atoms. Unlike the nickel 5-aminonapthalene-2-sulfonate salt, the amino group in this case is protonated and does not interact with the metal. As a result of the all-oxygen coordination, the crystals are the expected green color. The direct metal–sulfonate coordination is highly unusual for a divalent first-row transition metal, particularly in the absence of simultaneous amine coordination as is found in the sulfanilate salts. We are not aware of any other examples for nickel, though a study of the hydration of Ni(II) in the presence of poly(styrenesulfonate) in solution found “evidence for direct contacts between Ni2+ and oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups.”34

The extended structure is again layered, although in this case one can envision layering in two different directions. First, planes of cations parallel to a–b alternate with layers of cofacial naphthalenedisulfonate anions, pairs of which are related by inversion at the center of the unit cell. The cation and anion layers are linked by the Ni1–O1 bonds. Four additional water molecules of crystallization per formula unit are present, two associated with the coordinated waters in the metal layers, and two associated with the sulfonate and ammonio groups in the anion layers. Alternatively, one can view the structure as composed of metal layers parallel to the a–c plane with the anions in between. Both patterns have a single inorganic–organic layer as the repeat unit. Since only one of the six sulfonate O atoms interacts directly with the nickel cation, it is also possible to view the structure as consisting of discrete molecular [Ni(H2O)4(H3NC10H5(SO3)2)2] complexes that pack so as to afford π–π interactions between the naphthalene rings (interplanar C–C contacts ∼3.41 Å).

Pleasant48859MichiganUSA2grid.264756.40000000446872082Department of ChemistryTexas A&M UniversityCollege Station77843TexasUSAbp.squattrito@cmich.edu7620068200636848750120122005296200520122005762006© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 20062006Salts of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate with divalent Mg, Mn, Co, and Ni cations have been crystallized and their structures determined by single crystal X-ray methods. The Mg, Mn, and Co salts are isostructural. Crystal data for hexaaquamagnesium(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Mg(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.1329(18) Å, b=8.5789(11) Å, c=12.4880(17) Å, β=93.374(3)°, V=1511.5(3) Å3; hexaaquamanganese(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.249(3) Å, b=8.5940(17) Å, c=12.505(3) Å, β=93.30(3)°, V=1528.8(6) Å3; hexaaquacobalt(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.1406(18) Å, b=8.5674(11) Å, c=12.4960(16) Å, β=93.297(2)°, V=1511.4(3) Å3. The structures are composed of alternating layers of octahedral metal-aqua complexes and sulfonate anions linked by hydrogen bonds. The three water molecules of crystallization are associated with the hexaaquametal cations and sulfonate O atoms. The repeat unit along the a-axis is a single layer. The Ni salt [crystal data for tetraaquabis(5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonato-N)nickel(II) dihydrate, [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]⋅2H2O: triclinic, \documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$P\bar 1$$\end{document}, Z=1, a=6.8524(10) Å, b=8.3094(12) Å, c=11.4832(17) Å, α=69.003(2)°, β=76.570(3)°, γ=83.952(2)°, V=593.56(15) Å3] has a very different structure with direct coordination of the amine N atom to Ni, a modified stacking pattern, and fewer free water molecules. Ag and Ni salts of an amine-substituted naphthalenedisulfonate have also been characterized. Crystal data for diaqua(6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonato-O)silver(I) hydrate,[Ag(H2O)2(H3NC10H5(SO3)2)]⋅0.42H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=9.099(3) Å, b=21.406(6) Å, c=7.629(2) Å, β=110.178(4)°, V=1394.9(7) Å3; tetraaquabis (6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonato-O)nickel(II)tetrahydrate, [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H5 (SO3)2)2]⋅4H2O: triclinic,\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$P\bar 1$$\end{document}, Z=1, a=6.7971(17) Å, b=10.661(3) Å, c=11.165(3) Å, α=68.308(4)°, β=88.292(5)°, γ=84.896(5)°, V=748.8(3) Å3. The silver salt contains six coordinate metal centers each of which bonds to four sulfonate O atoms from three different anions and two water molecules. The nickel salt contains octahedral cations with four water molecules and two trans sulfonate O atoms. Both structures are layered, but differently from each other and from those of the monofunctional naphthalenesulfonate salts.KEY WORDS:Sulfonate saltsmagnesium complexesmanganese complexescobalt complexesnickel complexessilver complexeslayered structuresvolume-issue-count12issue-article-count10issue-toc-levels0issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2006article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2005article-registration-date-month12article-registration-date-day20article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2005_Article_9063.pdfoutput-mediumOnlinetarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2006issue-online-date-month9issue-online-date-day1issue-print-date-year2006issue-print-date-month9issue-print-date-day1issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryCrystallography journal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistry open-accessfalseUnusual coordination of a sulfonate group to a transition metal and coordination of an amine group to nickel but not to cobalt or manganese have been observed in a series of metal aminonaphthalenesulfonate saltsIntroductionCompounds with structures composed of alternating inorganic and organic domains have been of interest over the past two decades for their potential to act as host structures for various chemical processes.1,2 Among the most widely studied have been metal organophosphonate salts of the general formula Mm(O3PR)n⋅xH2O in which R is an aliphatic or aromatic organic group. The oxygen atoms of the phosphonate group coordinate to the metal ion, sometimes along with some water molecules. Most commonly, a two-dimensional metal-oxygen-phosphorus framework is formed, though chain and three-dimensional structures are also known.3-8 In all these materials, the R groups act as spacers between the inorganic parts. The resulting structures have rigid covalent inorganic frameworks separated by weakly interacting organic moieties. The use of different organic groups alters the size and nature of the organic region, and hence the physical properties of the material. More recently, we and others have explored the structural chemistry of analogous organosulfonate salts Mm(O3SR)n⋅xH2O and have found both similarities to and differences from the corresponding phosphonates. Particular attention has been focused on various arenesulfonates, including benzene9-13 and naphthalene14-21 derivatives. As an extension of these studies, we have synthesized and structurally characterized four salts of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and two salts of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid in order to compare the coordination behaviors and packing patterns to those of related naphthalenesulfonates with different substitution patterns (Scheme 1). ExperimentalSyntheses and thermal analysesMg(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O. A 1.500 g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid (Aldrich, >95%) was mixed with a 0.186 g (3.2 mmol) sample of magnesium hydroxide (Amend Drug & Chemical) in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 15 min. The resulting clear maroon solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm) pale mauve diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (this and subsequent reactions were repeated three times: average yield 1.06 g, 48%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the crystals performed from 50 to 800°C at a 20°C/min gradient shows two distinct mass losses centered at roughly 333 and 408 K each corresponding to loss of six molecules of water per formula unit. Presumably, the first six are the waters of crystallization while the second six are those coordinated to the Mg cation. The resulting anhydrous metal sulfonate is stable up to ca. 773 K where a further mass loss (~16%) occurs as decomposition of the organic commences.Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O. A 1.500g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid was combined with 0.366 g (3.2 mmol) of manganese(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) in 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 1 h. The resulting clear dark purple solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm), pale violet diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (average yield 0.76 g, 33%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. TGA of the crystals shows a split mass loss centered at 346 and 387 K, less well resolved than that of the Mg compound. The total mass loss of ~29.5% that is complete at 502 K corresponds to loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit (theoretical 30.2%). The anhydrous sulfonate salt is stable to further mass loss up to approximately 775 K.[Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2OThe synthesis of this compound was carried out similarly to that of the Mg compound, using 0.311 g (3.3 mmol) of cobalt(II) hydroxide (Aldrich, tech. 95%) and 1.502 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid. The resulting dark purple solution was gravity-filtered and set out at room temperature in an open container. After the solvent had evaporated, numerous large (up to 4 mm in diameter) red purple plate-like, diamond-shaped crystals of the product (average yield 1.69 g, 71%) were separated manually from the polycrystalline residue. In the TGA of the crystals, there were two distinct and roughly equal mass losses centered at 332 and 405 K. The total mass loss of about 31% that is complete by 435 K is consistent with loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit. Subsequent decomposition of the anhydrous material, as indicated by renewed mass loss (~29%), begins at roughly 805 K.[Ni(H2O)4 (H2NC10H6 SO3)2] ⋅ 2H2OThis compound was prepared according to the same procedure as the Mn compound, using 1.503 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and 0.375 g (3.2 mmol) of nickel(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent). An average of 1.58 g of dark purple diamond-shaped plates were collected for an 82% yield based on Ni. The TGA of these crystals showed a continuous mass loss of ~19% complete by 392 K. This mass loss is slightly above the 17.7% loss expected for six molecules of H2O and is most likely due to some additional hydration of the crystals that may have occurred on standing. The similarity in crystal morphology to the Mg, Mn, and Co compounds suggests that the Ni compound should be isomorphous, however the color (purple) is consistent with the coordination environment of the Ni as determined by the X-ray analysis. As for the other compounds in this series, the anhydrous metal sulfonate shows good thermal stability and does not begin to decompose to volatile products until about 810 K.[Ag (H2O)2 (H3NC10H5 (SO3)2)] ⋅ 0.42H2OA 1.504 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt (Eastman Organic Chemicals) and 1.464 g (8.6 mmol) of silver nitrate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting pale olive green solution was allowed to react for approximately 1 h, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Upon evaporation of most of the water, a thick mat of long pale yellow needle-shaped crystals was isolated from the bottom of the dish (average yield 2.27 g, >100% due to residual moisture in the product). TGA revealed a mass loss of approximately 7% complete by 375 K. This is somewhat less than the 9.6% expected based on the formula obtained from the X-ray structure. Given that the water of crystallization in this compound is present at partial occupancy, it is possible that the low water count obtained from the TGA is due to loss of water from the crystals prior to analysis. If only the coordinated water were retained in the structure, the expected mass loss on dehydration would be 8.1%. The rest of the TGA shows that this compound is less thermally stable than the others, with a series of significant mass losses beginning at 485 K. Unlike the divalent sulfonates, essentially the entire mass of the silver compound is ultimately volatilized by ~890 K.[Ni (H2O)4 (H3NC10H5 (SO3)2)2]⋅ 4H2OA 1.500 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt and 1.255 g (4.3 mmol) of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Aldrich) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting green solution was stirred for 20 min, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Evaporation of the water yielded many long green needles of the product (average yield 0.86 g, 25%), which were recovered manually from the polycrystalline residue. TGA showed a ~20% mass loss complete by 490 K that is somewhat higher than the 17.9% expected for loss of eight water molecules per formula unit. This discrepancy could be due to residual moisture in the sample. The dehydrated material is stable up to 630 K, where a large (~35%) mass loss begins. Thus, both salts of the 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate are less thermally stable than the salts of the 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate.Crystallographic studiesData collections (1.4°< θ < 28.2°) were performed at 110, 273, or 293 K on a Bruker Smart CCD-1000 diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ=0.71073 Å) radiation and an OXFORD cool stream low-temperature control unit using liquid nitrogen gas as coolant. Data reduction, cell refinement, and multiscan absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT program.22 The cell parameters were indexed from reflections obtained from 60 frames with an exposure of 10 s/frame. Full-spheres of data (2400 frames at 5 cm detector distances) were collected by the narrow-frame method with frame widths of 0.03° in θ and exposure time of 20-30 s/frame. The first 50 frames were recorded at the end of data collection to assess the stability of the crystals, and the decay in intensity was found to be less than 1% in all cases. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXTL-9723) with atomic coordinates and anisotropic displacement parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms. For the silver 6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate structure, a peak corresponding to the oxygen atom of a disordered water molecule was refined with variable occupancy factor to arrive at the observed formula. Hydrogen atoms for this water molecule could not be located. All other hydrogen atoms were located on difference electron density maps and were refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Crystallographic data for the structures are provided in Tables 1-3. Structural diagrams were generated using the CrystalMaker24 program. Results and discussionThe compounds [Mg(H2O)6] (H2NC10H6 SO3)2⋅6H2O, [Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O, and [Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O are isostructural. Their molecular structure is presented in Fig. 1, a packing diagram showing the unit cell is provided in Fig. 2,  and a view onto a single anion layer is given in Fig. 3. The metal cation rests on an inversion center and is coordinated to six water molecules in a highly regular octahedron as indicated by the bond distances and angles in Tables 4 and 5. There is no direct metal coordination by the sulfonate oxygen atoms or amine N atom. The range of Mg-O, Mn-O, and Co-O distances (Table 4) are similar to those reported for other hexaaqua complexes of these cations.25,26 There are also three noncoordinating water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The sulfonate group is positioned as in other naphthalenesulfonates15,19 with one oxygen atom (O3) nearly eclipsing the ring. The bond distances and angles about the S atom are consistent with those seen in similar compounds, including the modest opening of the O-S-O angles and narrowing of the O-S-C angles from the ideal tetrahedral value.The extended structure shows layers (parallel to the b-c plane) of anions alternating with layers of cations (Fig. 2), which is the typical motif for divalent sulfonate salts.20 Each anion layer contains pairs of cofacial naphthalene rings related by centers of inversion (Fig. 3) so that the SO3- and NH2 groups are directed to opposite sides of the layer in an alternating fashion in the c-direction. Anions with the same orientation repeat to form rows that extend along b. Anions related by the inversion center at z=1/2 are canted approximately 108° with respect to those centered about the symmetry elements at z=0 (Fig. 3). This type of staggered herringbone arrangement has been observed previously in the nickel and cobalt salts of 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate.19 The layers are held together by a strong network of approximately linear O-H⋯O and N-H⋯O hydrogen bonds involving the amino, water, and sulfonate groups. Two of the three free water molecules per formula unit are located in between the metal complexes in the inorganic layer, while the third is associated with the sulfonate group. The layers are arranged such that the repeat unit in the stacking direction consists of a single inorganic-organic layer. This structural motif is somewhat unusual for metal arene-monosulfonate salts, which mostly form double-layer repeat structures (i.e., inorganic-organic-inorganic-organic).14,15,19 The cell length along the stacking direction a of ~14.2 Å, representing the thickness of a single inorganic-organic slab, is greater than the ~11.6 Å observed for the Mg and Mn salts of 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate19 and the ~13.5 Å found in alkali metal salts of 6-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate.14 These differences represent the change in orientation of the naphthalene ring system with respect to the stacking direction. In all cases, the anions pack with the polar/charged groups (NH2 and SO3-) on the surfaces of the layer where interactions with cations and water are maximized. The 4,1 isomer has these groups para to each other on the same ring, so that the anions are arranged with the long direction of the naphthalene ring system approximately parallel to the layer. The 5,2 isomer has the long  direction of the ring system much closer to perpendicular to the layer rather than parallel. The 6,2 isomer, in which the polar groups are as far apart as possible, stacks with the long direction of the ring system nearly perpendicular to the layer. The reason the intralayer distance is not longer for these salts is that the alkali metals bond directly to the sulfonate oxygen atoms. Presumably, hexaaquametal salts of the 6,2 anion would in fact have the thickest slabs among these isomers. This behavior demonstrates that the nature and arrangement of substituent groups on arenesulfonates is an important factor in determining the exact structure adopted by salts of these anions with given metal ions. Surprisingly, the nickel salt of this sulfonate, [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]⋅2H2O, is different in both formula and structure from the Mg, Mn, and Co compounds. The molecular structure is shown in Fig. 4 and the packing structure is depicted in Fig. 5. The nickel cation is octahedrally coordinated by four water molecules and two amino N atoms on the sulfonate anions. The N atoms are trans as required by the inversion symmetry of the Ni site. The coordination of the amino group, while unmistakable from the crystal structure, is also indicated by the purple color of the crystals which is indicative of octahedral Ni(II) in a nitrogen ligand environment. That direct coordination of the amino group occurs for Ni only in this series may reflect the greater affinity of nickel(II) for N donors compared to the other divalent cations. The stepwise and overall formation constants for [Ni(NH3)1-6]2+ are all greater than the corresponding values for Co2+, and of course much greater than those of Mn2+ or Mg2+.27 Nevertheless, in our previous study of the 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate isomer, the Mg, Mn, Co, and Ni salts all contained fully aquated metal ions.19 Another amino-substituted sulfonate that has been widely studied with divalent transition metals is the sulfanilate anion (para-aminobenzenesulfonate), for which the Mg,25 Mn,28 and Co29 salts have been reported. All have different structures. In the sulfanilate structures, direct metal coordination occurs to the sulfonate O atoms and amino N atoms for Mn and Co while not for Mg, which is fully hydrated.  A simple Ni sulfanilate salt has not been reported, however, a diaquabis(1,3-propanediamine)nickel(II) sulfanilate compound shows no direct coordination between the nickel ion and the sulfanilate anion.30 By contrast, Mn and Co salts of 2-aminotoluene-4-sulfonate31 are both fully hydrated (no amine or sulfonate coordination), while the Ni salt has not been characterized. Clearly, additional studies are needed to establish the extent to which nickel is unique in these systems.The extended structure of [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]⋅2H2O shows the familiar arrangement of alternating layers of cations and anions, in this case parallel to the a-b plane and stacking along c. The anions are again packing with the SO3- and NH2 groups on adjacent anions in opposite up and down orientations. The sulfonate group is positioned somewhat differently with respect to the ring system, as indicated by the ~27° O3-S1-C2-C3 torsion angle (Table 5). As was the case with the Mg, Mn, and Co salts, the repeat unit is a single layer, though the repeat distance along c (~11.5 Å) is much shorter in the Ni compound since the anion layers are linked directly to the cations through the amino group. Perhaps for this same reason, there are only one-third as many free water molecules in this structure: two water molecules of crystallization per formula unit or one per asymmetric unit, found in the cation layer. The more compact packing is reflected in the greater density of the Ni salt compared to the Co salt (Table 2).Two new structures of a naphthalenedisulfonate have also been determined. The molecular structure of [Ag(H2O)2 (H3NC10H5(SO3)2)]⋅0.42H2O is presented in Fig. 6, while two views of the extended structure are shown in Figs. 7 and 8. The compound crystallized with one silver(I) cation, one protonated 6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate anion, two coordinated water molecules, and one water molecule of crystallization at partial (~42%) occupancy in the asymmetric unit. The silver ion is in a distorted sixfold coordination of four sulfonate O atoms from three different anions and two water molecules. According to the bond distances (Table 4), there are four closer interactions with Ag-O distances in the typical range for silver sulfonates21,32 and two somewhat more distant (but nevertheless significant) interactions. Direct coordination of sulfonate groups to monovalent cations with only moderate amounts of water present is a common characteristic of silver21 and alkali metal9,14 sulfonate salts. Cote and Shimizu21 have postulated that arenesulfonates below a certain width will form salts with silver in which the layers contain an (-Ag-O-S-) network with no water, while larger aryl groups will prevent the necessary compactness of such structures, with the result that water is included to supplement the coordination of the metal. Although his analysis was limited to monosulfonates without other substituents, the protonation of the amino group in our case renders the stoichiometry the same. Thus, it seems fair to conclude that the steric demands of the 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate are sufficient to preclude the formation of an anhydrous coordination network. The absence of direct coordination to the amino group is contrary to what is found in silver sulfanilate.33Of the coordinated sulfonate anions, two are monodentate, through O1 and O2 [generated by inversion center at (1/2 1 1/2)], while the third is bidentate through O5 and O6 [generated by inversion center at (0 1 0)]. Two oxygen atoms on each sulfonate group bond to a silver ion, while one does not. Of the O atoms that do not interact with Ag, one (O4) has a noticeably short S-O bond length while the other (O3) does not. The sulfonate groups are arranged with one O atom approximately eclipsing the naphthalene ring. As shown in Fig. 6, the silver ions bridge the sulfonate anions in such a way as to create dimeric units with 16-membered rings of two Ag, four O, four S, and six C atoms. These units are not isolated, but rather linked in a three-dimensional network via the connections to other anions through O2. The resulting extended structure is layered, with silver ions just off the a-c plane in a slightly ruffled array alternating with the anions. The anions are arranged so that the naphthalene rings are approximately parallel (Fig. 7), but adjacent anions along c have their rings tilted in the opposite directions with respect to the stacking direction (Fig. 8). The repeat unit is a double layer, with silver layers centered at y=0 and 1/2 and anion layers at y=1/4 and 3/4. The b-axis length indicates a layer thickness of ~11.7 Å, reflecting the tilting of the rings as well as the direct bonding between the cations and anions.The molecular structure of [Ni(H2O)4(H3NC10H5(SO3)2)2]⋅4H2O is depicted in Fig. 9, while a view of the packing is provided in Fig. 10. The nickel(II) ion is located on a center of inversion and is octahedrally coordinated by four water molecules and two sulfonate O atoms. Unlike the nickel 5-aminonapthalene-2-sulfonate salt, the amino group in this case is protonated and does not interact with the metal. As a result of the all-oxygen coordination, the crystals are the expected green color. The direct metal-sulfonate coordination is highly unusual for a divalent first-row transition metal, particularly in the absence of simultaneous amine coordination as is found in the sulfanilate salts. We are not aware of any other examples for nickel, though a study of the hydration of Ni(II) in the presence of poly(styrenesulfonate) in solution found "evidence for direct contacts between Ni2+ and oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups."34The extended structure is again layered, although in this case one can envision layering in two different directions. First, planes of cations parallel to a-b alternate with layers of cofacial naphthalenedisulfonate anions, pairs of which are related by inversion at the center of the unit cell. The cation and anion layers are linked by the Ni1-O1 bonds. Four additional water molecules of crystallization per formula unit are present, two associated with the coordinated waters in the metal layers, and two associated with the sulfonate and ammonio groups in the anion  layers. Alternatively, one can view the structure as composed of metal layers parallel to the a-c plane with the anions in between. Both patterns have a single inorganic-organic layer as the repeat unit. Since only one of the six sulfonate O atoms interacts directly with the nickel cation, it is also possible to view the structure as consisting of discrete molecular [Ni(H2O)4(H3NC10H5(SO3)2)2] complexes that pack so as to afford π-π interactions between the naphthalene rings (interplanar C-C contacts ~3.41 Å). elements.content: Salts of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate with divalent Mg, Mn, Co, and Ni cations have been crystallized and their structures determined by single crystal X-ray methods. The Mg, Mn, and Co salts are isostructural. Crystal data for hexaaquamagnesium(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Mg(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.1329(18) Å, b=8.5789(11) Å, c=12.4880(17) Å, β=93.374(3)°, V=1511.5(3) Å3; hexaaquamanganese(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.249(3) Å, b=8.5940(17) Å, c=12.505(3) Å, β=93.30(3)°, V=1528.8(6) Å3; hexaaquacobalt(II) 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate hexahydrate, [Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O: monoclinic, P21/c, Z=2, a=14.1406(18) Å, b=8.5674(11) Å, c=12.4960(16) Å, β=93.297(2)°, V=1511.4(3) Å3. The structures are composed of alternating layers of octahedral metal–aqua complexes and sulfonate anions linked by hydrogen bonds. The three water molecules of crystallization are associated with the hexaaquametal cations and sulfonate O atoms. The repeat unit along the a-axis is a single layer. The Ni salt [crystal data for tetraaquabis(5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonato-N)nickel(II) dihydrate, [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]·2H2O: triclinic, \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$P\bar 1$$\end{document}, Z=1, a=6.8524(10) Å, b=8.3094(12) Å, c=11.4832(17) Å, α=69.003(2)°, β=76.570(3)°, γ=83.952(2)°, V=593.56(15) Å3] has a very different structure with direct coordination of the amine N atom to Ni, a modified stacking pattern, and fewer free water molecules. Ag and Ni salts of an amine-substituted naphthalenedisulfonate have also been characterized. Crystal data for diaqua(6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonato-O)silver(I) hydrate,

elements.content: Compounds with structures composed of alternating inorganic and organic domains have been of interest over the past two decades for their potential to act as host structures for various chemical processes.1,2 Among the most widely studied have been metal organophosphonate salts of the general formula Mm(O3PR)n·xH2O in which R is an aliphatic or aromatic organic group. The oxygen atoms of the phosphonate group coordinate to the metal ion, sometimes along with some water molecules. Most commonly, a two-dimensional metal–oxygen–phosphorus framework is formed, though chain and three-dimensional structures are also known.3-8 In all these materials, the R groups act as spacers between the inorganic parts. The resulting structures have rigid covalent inorganic frameworks separated by weakly interacting organic moieties. The use of different organic groups alters the size and nature of the organic region, and hence the physical properties of the material. More recently, we and others have explored the structural chemistry of analogous organosulfonate salts Mm(O3SR)n·xH2O and have found both similarities to and differences from the corresponding phosphonates. Particular attention has been focused on various arenesulfonates, including benzene9–13 and naphthalene14–21 derivatives. As an extension of these studies, we have synthesized and structurally characterized four salts of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and two salts of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid in order to compare the coordination behaviors and packing patterns to those of related naphthalenesulfonates with different substitution patterns (Scheme 1).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Compounds with structures composed of alternating inorganic and organic domains have been of interest over the past two decades for their potential to act as host structures for various chemical processes.1,2 Among the most widely studied have been metal organophosphonate salts of the general formula Mm(O3PR)n⋅xH2O in which R is an aliphatic or aromatic organic group. The oxygen atoms of the phosphonate group coordinate to the metal ion, sometimes along with some water molecules. Most commonly, a two-dimensional metal-oxygen-phosphorus framework is formed, though chain and three-dimensional structures are also known.3-8 In all these materials, the R groups act as spacers between the inorganic parts. The resulting structures have rigid covalent inorganic frameworks separated by weakly interacting organic moieties. The use of different organic groups alters the size and nature of the organic region, and hence the physical properties of the material. More recently, we and others have explored the structural chemistry of analogous organosulfonate salts Mm(O3SR)n⋅xH2O and have found both similarities to and differences from the corresponding phosphonates. Particular attention has been focused on various arenesulfonates, including benzene9-13 and naphthalene14-21 derivatives. As an extension of these studies, we have synthesized and structurally characterized four salts of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and two salts of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid in order to compare the coordination behaviors and packing patterns to those of related naphthalenesulfonates with different substitution patterns (Scheme 1).

Mg(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O. A 1.500 g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid (Aldrich, >95%) was mixed with a 0.186 g (3.2 mmol) sample of magnesium hydroxide (Amend Drug & Chemical) in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 15 min. The resulting clear maroon solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm) pale mauve diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (this and subsequent reactions were repeated three times: average yield 1.06 g, 48%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the crystals performed from 50 to 800°C at a 20°C/min gradient shows two distinct mass losses centered at roughly 333 and 408 K each corresponding to loss of six molecules of water per formula unit. Presumably, the first six are the waters of crystallization while the second six are those coordinated to the Mg cation. The resulting anhydrous metal sulfonate is stable up to ca. 773 K where a further mass loss (∼16%) occurs as decomposition of the organic commences.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Syntheses and thermal analyses

Mg(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O. A 1.500 g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid (Aldrich, >95%) was mixed with a 0.186 g (3.2 mmol) sample of magnesium hydroxide (Amend Drug & Chemical) in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 15 min. The resulting clear maroon solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm) pale mauve diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (this and subsequent reactions were repeated three times: average yield 1.06 g, 48%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the crystals performed from 50 to 800°C at a 20°C/min gradient shows two distinct mass losses centered at roughly 333 and 408 K each corresponding to loss of six molecules of water per formula unit. Presumably, the first six are the waters of crystallization while the second six are those coordinated to the Mg cation. The resulting anhydrous metal sulfonate is stable up to ca. 773 K where a further mass loss (~16%) occurs as decomposition of the organic commences.

elements.content: Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O. A 1.500g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid was combined with 0.366 g (3.2 mmol) of manganese(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) in 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 1 h. The resulting clear dark purple solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm), pale violet diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (average yield 0.76 g, 33%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. TGA of the crystals shows a split mass loss centered at 346 and 387 K, less well resolved than that of the Mg compound. The total mass loss of ∼29.5% that is complete at 502 K corresponds to loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit (theoretical 30.2%). The anhydrous sulfonate salt is stable to further mass loss up to approximately 775 K.

A 1.500g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid was combined with 0.366 g (3.2 mmol) of manganese(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) in 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 1 h. The resulting clear dark purple solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm), pale violet diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (average yield 0.76 g, 33%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. TGA of the crystals shows a split mass loss centered at 346 and 387 K, less well resolved than that of the Mg compound. The total mass loss of ~29.5% that is complete at 502 K corresponds to loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit (theoretical 30.2%). The anhydrous sulfonate salt is stable to further mass loss up to approximately 775 K.

The synthesis of this compound was carried out similarly to that of the Mg compound, using 0.311 g (3.3 mmol) of cobalt(II) hydroxide (Aldrich, tech. 95%) and 1.502 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid. The resulting dark purple solution was gravity-filtered and set out at room temperature in an open container. After the solvent had evaporated, numerous large (up to 4 mm in diameter) red purple plate-like, diamond-shaped crystals of the product (average yield 1.69 g, 71%) were separated manually from the polycrystalline residue. In the TGA of the crystals, there were two distinct and roughly equal mass losses centered at 332 and 405 K. The total mass loss of about 31% that is complete by 435 K is consistent with loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit. Subsequent decomposition of the anhydrous material, as indicated by renewed mass loss (∼29%), begins at roughly 805 K.

elements.content: This compound was prepared according to the same procedure as the Mn compound, using 1.503 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and 0.375 g (3.2 mmol) of nickel(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent). An average of 1.58 g of dark purple diamond-shaped plates were collected for an 82% yield based on Ni. The TGA of these crystals showed a continuous mass loss of ∼19% complete by 392 K. This mass loss is slightly above the 17.7% loss expected for six molecules of H2O and is most likely due to some additional hydration of the crystals that may have occurred on standing. The similarity in crystal morphology to the Mg, Mn, and Co compounds suggests that the Ni compound should be isomorphous, however the color (purple) is consistent with the coordination environment of the Ni as determined by the X-ray analysis. As for the other compounds in this series, the anhydrous metal sulfonate shows good thermal stability and does not begin to decompose to volatile products until about 810 K.

elements.content: A 1.504 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt (Eastman Organic Chemicals) and 1.464 g (8.6 mmol) of silver nitrate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting pale olive green solution was allowed to react for approximately 1 h, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Upon evaporation of most of the water, a thick mat of long pale yellow needle-shaped crystals was isolated from the bottom of the dish (average yield 2.27 g, >100% due to residual moisture in the product). TGA revealed a mass loss of approximately 7% complete by 375 K. This is somewhat less than the 9.6% expected based on the formula obtained from the X-ray structure. Given that the water of crystallization in this compound is present at partial occupancy, it is possible that the low water count obtained from the TGA is due to loss of water from the crystals prior to analysis. If only the coordinated water were retained in the structure, the expected mass loss on dehydration would be 8.1%. The rest of the TGA shows that this compound is less thermally stable than the others, with a series of significant mass losses beginning at 485 K. Unlike the divalent sulfonates, essentially the entire mass of the silver compound is ultimately volatilized by ∼890 K.

elements.content: A 1.500 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt and 1.255 g (4.3 mmol) of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Aldrich) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting green solution was stirred for 20 min, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Evaporation of the water yielded many long green needles of the product (average yield 0.86 g, 25%), which were recovered manually from the polycrystalline residue. TGA showed a ∼20% mass loss complete by 490 K that is somewhat higher than the 17.9% expected for loss of eight water molecules per formula unit. This discrepancy could be due to residual moisture in the sample. The dehydrated material is stable up to 630 K, where a large (∼35%) mass loss begins. Thus, both salts of the 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate are less thermally stable than the salts of the 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate.

elements.content: Data collections (1.4°< θ < 28.2°) were performed at 110, 273, or 293 K on a Bruker Smart CCD-1000 diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ=0.71073 Å) radiation and an OXFORD cool stream low-temperature control unit using liquid nitrogen gas as coolant. Data reduction, cell refinement, and multiscan absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT program.22 The cell parameters were indexed from reflections obtained from 60 frames with an exposure of 10 s/frame. Full-spheres of data (2400 frames at 5 cm detector distances) were collected by the narrow-frame method with frame widths of 0.03° in θ and exposure time of 20–30 s/frame. The first 50 frames were recorded at the end of data collection to assess the stability of the crystals, and the decay in intensity was found to be less than 1% in all cases. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXTL-9723) with atomic coordinates and anisotropic displacement parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms. For the silver 6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate structure, a peak corresponding to the oxygen atom of a disordered water molecule was refined with variable occupancy factor to arrive at the observed formula. Hydrogen atoms for this water molecule could not be located. All other hydrogen atoms were located on difference electron density maps and were refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Crystallographic data for the structures are provided in Tables 1–3. Structural diagrams were generated using the CrystalMaker24 program.

Crystallographic studies

Data collections (1.4°< θ < 28.2°) were performed at 110, 273, or 293 K on a Bruker Smart CCD-1000 diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ=0.71073 Å) radiation and an OXFORD cool stream low-temperature control unit using liquid nitrogen gas as coolant. Data reduction, cell refinement, and multiscan absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT program.22 The cell parameters were indexed from reflections obtained from 60 frames with an exposure of 10 s/frame. Full-spheres of data (2400 frames at 5 cm detector distances) were collected by the narrow-frame method with frame widths of 0.03° in θ and exposure time of 20-30 s/frame. The first 50 frames were recorded at the end of data collection to assess the stability of the crystals, and the decay in intensity was found to be less than 1% in all cases. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXTL-9723) with atomic coordinates and anisotropic displacement parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms. For the silver 6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate structure, a peak corresponding to the oxygen atom of a disordered water molecule was refined with variable occupancy factor to arrive at the observed formula. Hydrogen atoms for this water molecule could not be located. All other hydrogen atoms were located on difference electron density maps and were refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Crystallographic data for the structures are provided in Tables 1-3. Structural diagrams were generated using the CrystalMaker24 program.

Symmetry equivalent water molecules have been included to show the octahedral coordination of the magnesium ion [symmetry operation (#): –x, –y, –z+1]. The Mn and Co compounds are isostructural.

Symmetry equivalent water molecules have been included to show the octahedral coordination of the magnesium ion [symmetry operation (#): -x, -y, -z+1]. The Mn and Co compounds are isostructural.

elements.content: The compounds [Mg(H2O)6] (H2NC10H6 SO3)2·6H2O, [Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O, and [Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O are isostructural. Their molecular structure is presented in Fig. 1, a packing diagram showing the unit cell is provided in Fig. 2, and a view onto a single anion layer is given in Fig. 3. The metal cation rests on an inversion center and is coordinated to six water molecules in a highly regular octahedron as indicated by the bond distances and angles in Tables 4 and 5. There is no direct metal coordination by the sulfonate oxygen atoms or amine N atom. The range of Mg–O, Mn–O, and Co–O distances (Table 4) are similar to those reported for other hexaaqua complexes of these cations.25,26 There are also three noncoordinating water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The sulfonate group is positioned as in other naphthalenesulfonates15,19 with one oxygen atom (O3) nearly eclipsing the ring. The bond distances and angles about the S atom are consistent with those seen in similar compounds, including the modest opening of the O–S–O angles and narrowing of the O–S–C angles from the ideal tetrahedral value.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The compounds [Mg(H2O)6] (H2NC10H6 SO3)2⋅6H2O, [Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O, and [Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O are isostructural. Their molecular structure is presented in Fig. 1, a packing diagram showing the unit cell is provided in Fig. 2,  and a view onto a single anion layer is given in Fig. 3. The metal cation rests on an inversion center and is coordinated to six water molecules in a highly regular octahedron as indicated by the bond distances and angles in Tables 4 and 5. There is no direct metal coordination by the sulfonate oxygen atoms or amine N atom. The range of Mg-O, Mn-O, and Co-O distances (Table 4) are similar to those reported for other hexaaqua complexes of these cations.25,26 There are also three noncoordinating water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The sulfonate group is positioned as in other naphthalenesulfonates15,19 with one oxygen atom (O3) nearly eclipsing the ring. The bond distances and angles about the S atom are consistent with those seen in similar compounds, including the modest opening of the O-S-O angles and narrowing of the O-S-C angles from the ideal tetrahedral value.

elements.content: The extended structure shows layers (parallel to the b–c plane) of anions alternating with layers of cations (Fig. 2), which is the typical motif for divalent sulfonate salts.20 Each anion layer contains pairs of cofacial naphthalene rings related by centers of inversion (Fig. 3) so that the SO3− and NH2 groups are directed to opposite sides of the layer in an alternating fashion in the c-direction. Anions with the same orientation repeat to form rows that extend along b. Anions related by the inversion center at z=1/2 are canted approximately 108° with respect to those centered about the symmetry elements at z=0 (Fig. 3). This type of staggered herringbone arrangement has been observed previously in the nickel and cobalt salts of 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate.19 The layers are held together by a strong network of approximately linear O–H⋯O and N–H⋯O hydrogen bonds involving the amino, water, and sulfonate groups. Two of the three free water molecules per formula unit are located in between the metal complexes in the inorganic layer, while the third is associated with the sulfonate group. The layers are arranged such that the repeat unit in the stacking direction consists of a single inorganic–organic layer. This structural motif is somewhat unusual for metal arene-monosulfonate salts, which mostly form double-layer repeat structures (i.e., inorganic–organic–inorganic–organic).14,15,19 The cell length along the stacking direction a of ∼14.2 Å, representing the thickness of a single inorganic–organic slab, is greater than the ∼11.6 Å observed for the Mg and Mn salts of 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate19 and the ∼13.5 Å found in alkali metal salts of 6-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate.14 These differences represent the change in orientation of the naphthalene ring system with respect to the stacking direction. In all cases, the anions pack with the polar/charged groups (NH2 and SO3−) on the surfaces of the layer where interactions with cations and water are maximized. The 4,1 isomer has these groups para to each other on the same ring, so that the anions are arranged with the long direction of the naphthalene ring system approximately parallel to the layer. The 5,2 isomer has the long direction of the ring system much closer to perpendicular to the layer rather than parallel. The 6,2 isomer, in which the polar groups are as far apart as possible, stacks with the long direction of the ring system nearly perpendicular to the layer. The reason the intralayer distance is not longer for these salts is that the alkali metals bond directly to the sulfonate oxygen atoms. Presumably, hexaaquametal salts of the 6,2 anion would in fact have the thickest slabs among these isomers. This behavior demonstrates that the nature and arrangement of substituent groups on arenesulfonates is an important factor in determining the exact structure adopted by salts of these anions with given metal ions.

Surprisingly, the nickel salt of this sulfonate, [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]·2H2O, is different in both formula and structure from the Mg, Mn, and Co compounds. The molecular structure is shown in Fig. 4 and the packing structure is depicted in Fig. 5. The nickel cation is octahedrally coordinated by four water molecules and two amino N atoms on the sulfonate anions. The N atoms are trans as required by the inversion symmetry of the Ni site. The coordination of the amino group, while unmistakable from the crystal structure, is also indicated by the purple color of the crystals which is indicative of octahedral Ni(II) in a nitrogen ligand environment. That direct coordination of the amino group occurs for Ni only in this series may reflect the greater affinity of nickel(II) for N donors compared to the other divalent cations. The stepwise and overall formation constants for [Ni(NH3)1–6]2+ are all greater than the corresponding values for Co2+, and of course much greater than those of Mn2+ or Mg2+.27 Nevertheless, in our previous study of the 4-aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonate isomer, the Mg, Mn, Co, and Ni salts all contained fully aquated metal ions.19 Another amino-substituted sulfonate that has been widely studied with divalent transition metals is the sulfanilate anion (para-aminobenzenesulfonate), for which the Mg,25 Mn,28 and Co29 salts have been reported. All have different structures. In the sulfanilate structures, direct metal coordination occurs to the sulfonate O atoms and amino N atoms for Mn and Co while not for Mg, which is fully hydrated. A simple Ni sulfanilate salt has not been reported, however, a diaquabis(1,3-propanediamine)nickel(II) sulfanilate compound shows no direct coordination between the nickel ion and the sulfanilate anion.30 By contrast, Mn and Co salts of 2-aminotoluene-4-sulfonate31 are both fully hydrated (no amine or sulfonate coordination), while the Ni salt has not been characterized. Clearly, additional studies are needed to establish the extent to which nickel is unique in these systems.
