elements.content: The extended structure of [Ni(H2O)4(H2NC10H6SO3)2]·2H2O shows the familiar arrangement of alternating layers of cations and anions, in this case parallel to the a–b plane and stacking along c. The anions are again packing with the SO3− and NH2 groups on adjacent anions in opposite up and down orientations. The sulfonate group is positioned somewhat differently with respect to the ring system, as indicated by the ∼27° O3–S1–C2–C3 torsion angle (Table 5). As was the case with the Mg, Mn, and Co salts, the repeat unit is a single layer, though the repeat distance along c (∼11.5 Å) is much shorter in the Ni compound since the anion layers are linked directly to the cations through the amino group. Perhaps for this same reason, there are only one-third as many free water molecules in this structure: two water molecules of crystallization per formula unit or one per asymmetric unit, found in the cation layer. The more compact packing is reflected in the greater density of the Ni salt compared to the Co salt (Table 2).

elements.content: Two new structures of a naphthalenedisulfonate have also been determined. The molecular structure of [Ag(H2O)2 (H3NC10H5(SO3)2)]·0.42H2O is presented in Fig. 6, while two views of the extended structure are shown in Figs. 7 and 8. The compound crystallized with one silver(I) cation, one protonated 6-ammonionaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate anion, two coordinated water molecules, and one water molecule of crystallization at partial (∼42%) occupancy in the asymmetric unit. The silver ion is in a distorted sixfold coordination of four sulfonate O atoms from three different anions and two water molecules. According to the bond distances (Table 4), there are four closer interactions with Ag–O distances in the typical range for silver sulfonates21,32 and two somewhat more distant (but nevertheless significant) interactions. Direct coordination of sulfonate groups to monovalent cations with only moderate amounts of water present is a common characteristic of silver21 and alkali metal9,14 sulfonate salts. Cote and Shimizu21 have postulated that arenesulfonates below a certain width will form salts with silver in which the layers contain an (–Ag–O–S–) network with no water, while larger aryl groups will prevent the necessary compactness of such structures, with the result that water is included to supplement the coordination of the metal. Although his analysis was limited to monosulfonates without other substituents, the protonation of the amino group in our case renders the stoichiometry the same. Thus, it seems fair to conclude that the steric demands of the 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate are sufficient to preclude the formation of an anhydrous coordination network. The absence of direct coordination to the amino group is contrary to what is found in silver sulfanilate.33

elements.content: Of the coordinated sulfonate anions, two are monodentate, through O1 and O2 [generated by inversion center at (1/2 1 1/2)], while the third is bidentate through O5 and O6 [generated by inversion center at (0 1 0)]. Two oxygen atoms on each sulfonate group bond to a silver ion, while one does not. Of the O atoms that do not interact with Ag, one (O4) has a noticeably short S–O bond length while the other (O3) does not. The sulfonate groups are arranged with one O atom approximately eclipsing the naphthalene ring. As shown in Fig. 6, the silver ions bridge the sulfonate anions in such a way as to create dimeric units with 16-membered rings of two Ag, four O, four S, and six C atoms. These units are not isolated, but rather linked in a three-dimensional network via the connections to other anions through O2. The resulting extended structure is layered, with silver ions just off the a–c plane in a slightly ruffled array alternating with the anions. The anions are arranged so that the naphthalene rings are approximately parallel (Fig. 7), but adjacent anions along c have their rings tilted in the opposite directions with respect to the stacking direction (Fig. 8). The repeat unit is a double layer, with silver layers centered at y=0 and 1/2 and anion layers at y=1/4 and 3/4. The b-axis length indicates a layer thickness of ∼11.7 Å, reflecting the tilting of the rings as well as the direct bonding between the cations and anions.

elements.content: The molecular structure of [Ni(H2O)4(H3NC10H5(SO3)2)2]·4H2O is depicted in Fig. 9, while a view of the packing is provided in Fig. 10. The nickel(II) ion is located on a center of inversion and is octahedrally coordinated by four water molecules and two sulfonate O atoms. Unlike the nickel 5-aminonapthalene-2-sulfonate salt, the amino group in this case is protonated and does not interact with the metal. As a result of the all-oxygen coordination, the crystals are the expected green color. The direct metal–sulfonate coordination is highly unusual for a divalent first-row transition metal, particularly in the absence of simultaneous amine coordination as is found in the sulfanilate salts. We are not aware of any other examples for nickel, though a study of the hydration of Ni(II) in the presence of poly(styrenesulfonate) in solution found “evidence for direct contacts between Ni2+ and oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups.”34

As a result of the all-oxygen coordination, the crystals are the expected green color. The direct metal-sulfonate coordination is highly unusual for a divalent first-row transition metal, particularly in the absence of simultaneous amine coordination as is found in the sulfanilate salts. We are not aware of any other examples for nickel, though a study of the hydration of Ni(II) in the presence of poly(styrenesulfonate) in solution found "evidence for direct contacts between Ni2+ and oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups."34

elements.content: The extended structure is again layered, although in this case one can envision layering in two different directions. First, planes of cations parallel to a–b alternate with layers of cofacial naphthalenedisulfonate anions, pairs of which are related by inversion at the center of the unit cell. The cation and anion layers are linked by the Ni1–O1 bonds. Four additional water molecules of crystallization per formula unit are present, two associated with the coordinated waters in the metal layers, and two associated with the sulfonate and ammonio groups in the anion layers. Alternatively, one can view the structure as composed of metal layers parallel to the a–c plane with the anions in between. Both patterns have a single inorganic–organic layer as the repeat unit. Since only one of the six sulfonate O atoms interacts directly with the nickel cation, it is also possible to view the structure as consisting of discrete molecular [Ni(H2O)4(H3NC10H5(SO3)2)2] complexes that pack so as to afford π–π interactions between the naphthalene rings (interplanar C–C contacts ∼3.41 Å).

cln_elements.content:
Mg(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O. A 1.500 g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid (Aldrich, >95%) was mixed with a 0.186 g (3.2 mmol) sample of magnesium hydroxide (Amend Drug & Chemical) in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 15 min. The resulting clear maroon solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm) pale mauve diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (this and subsequent reactions were repeated three times: average yield 1.06 g, 48%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the crystals performed from 50 to 800°C at a 20°C/min gradient shows two distinct mass losses centered at roughly 333 and 408 K each corresponding to loss of six molecules of water per formula unit. Presumably, the first six are the waters of crystallization while the second six are those coordinated to the Mg cation. The resulting anhydrous metal sulfonate is stable up to ca. 773 K where a further mass loss (∼16%) occurs as decomposition of the organic commences.

Mn(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2·6H2O. A 1.500g (6.7 mmol) sample of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid was combined with 0.366 g (3.2 mmol) of manganese(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) in 50 mL of de-ionized water. The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 1 h. The resulting clear dark purple solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm), pale violet diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (average yield 0.76 g, 33%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. TGA of the crystals shows a split mass loss centered at 346 and 387 K, less well resolved than that of the Mg compound. The total mass loss of ∼29.5% that is complete at 502 K corresponds to loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit (theoretical 30.2%). The anhydrous sulfonate salt is stable to further mass loss up to approximately 775 K.

[Co(H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O)<sub><italic>6</italic></sub>](H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>NC<sub><italic>10</italic></sub>H<sub><italic>6</italic></sub>SO<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>·6H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O

The synthesis of this compound was carried out similarly to that of the Mg compound, using 0.311 g (3.3 mmol) of cobalt(II) hydroxide (Aldrich, tech. 95%) and 1.502 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid. The resulting dark purple solution was gravity-filtered and set out at room temperature in an open container. After the solvent had evaporated, numerous large (up to 4 mm in diameter) red purple plate-like, diamond-shaped crystals of the product (average yield 1.69 g, 71%) were separated manually from the polycrystalline residue. In the TGA of the crystals, there were two distinct and roughly equal mass losses centered at 332 and 405 K. The total mass loss of about 31% that is complete by 435 K is consistent with loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit. Subsequent decomposition of the anhydrous material, as indicated by renewed mass loss (∼29%), begins at roughly 805 K.

[Ni(H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O)<sub><italic>4</italic></sub> (H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>NC<sub><italic>10</italic></sub>H<sub><italic>6</italic></sub> SO<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>] · <italic>2</italic>H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O

This compound was prepared according to the same procedure as the Mn compound, using 1.503 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and 0.375 g (3.2 mmol) of nickel(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent). An average of 1.58 g of dark purple diamond-shaped plates were collected for an 82% yield based on Ni. The TGA of these crystals showed a continuous mass loss of ∼19% complete by 392 K. This mass loss is slightly above the 17.7% loss expected for six molecules of H2O and is most likely due to some additional hydration of the crystals that may have occurred on standing. The similarity in crystal morphology to the Mg, Mn, and Co compounds suggests that the Ni compound should be isomorphous, however the color (purple) is consistent with the coordination environment of the Ni as determined by the X-ray analysis. As for the other compounds in this series, the anhydrous metal sulfonate shows good thermal stability and does not begin to decompose to volatile products until about 810 K.

[Ag (H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub> (H<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>NC<sub><italic>10</italic></sub>H<sub><italic>5</italic></sub> (SO<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>)] · <italic>0.42H</italic><sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O

A 1.504 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt (Eastman Organic Chemicals) and 1.464 g (8.6 mmol) of silver nitrate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting pale olive green solution was allowed to react for approximately 1 h, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Upon evaporation of most of the water, a thick mat of long pale yellow needle-shaped crystals was isolated from the bottom of the dish (average yield 2.27 g, >100% due to residual moisture in the product). TGA revealed a mass loss of approximately 7% complete by 375 K. This is somewhat less than the 9.6% expected based on the formula obtained from the X-ray structure. Given that the water of crystallization in this compound is present at partial occupancy, it is possible that the low water count obtained from the TGA is due to loss of water from the crystals prior to analysis. If only the coordinated water were retained in the structure, the expected mass loss on dehydration would be 8.1%. The rest of the TGA shows that this compound is less thermally stable than the others, with a series of significant mass losses beginning at 485 K. Unlike the divalent sulfonates, essentially the entire mass of the silver compound is ultimately volatilized by ∼890 K.

[Ni (H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O)<sub><italic>4</italic></sub> (H<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>NC<sub><italic>10</italic></sub>H<sub><italic>5</italic></sub> (SO<sub><italic>3</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>)<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>]· <italic>4</italic>H<sub><italic>2</italic></sub>O

A 1.500 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt and 1.255 g (4.3 mmol) of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Aldrich) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting green solution was stirred for 20 min, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Evaporation of the water yielded many long green needles of the product (average yield 0.86 g, 25%), which were recovered manually from the polycrystalline residue. TGA showed a ∼20% mass loss complete by 490 K that is somewhat higher than the 17.9% expected for loss of eight water molecules per formula unit. This discrepancy could be due to residual moisture in the sample. The dehydrated material is stable up to 630 K, where a large (∼35%) mass loss begins. Thus, both salts of the 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate are less thermally stable than the salts of the 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate.

The initial cloudy lavender suspension was heated and allowed to react for about 1 h. The resulting clear dark purple solution was then gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish and left out at room temperature. Following complete evaporation of the solvent, many large (>2 mm), pale violet diamond-shaped plates of the product were recovered from the bottom of the dish (average yield 0.76 g, 33%). The remainder not collected was a polycrystalline crust on the sides of the dish. TGA of the crystals shows a split mass loss centered at 346 and 387 K, less well resolved than that of the Mg compound. The total mass loss of ~29.5% that is complete at 502 K corresponds to loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit (theoretical 30.2%). The anhydrous sulfonate salt is stable to further mass loss up to approximately 775 K.

[Co(H2O)6](H2NC10H6SO3)2⋅6H2O

The synthesis of this compound was carried out similarly to that of the Mg compound, using 0.311 g (3.3 mmol) of cobalt(II) hydroxide (Aldrich, tech. 95%) and 1.502 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid. The resulting dark purple solution was gravity-filtered and set out at room temperature in an open container. After the solvent had evaporated, numerous large (up to 4 mm in diameter) red purple plate-like, diamond-shaped crystals of the product (average yield 1.69 g, 71%) were separated manually from the polycrystalline residue. In the TGA of the crystals, there were two distinct and roughly equal mass losses centered at 332 and 405 K. The total mass loss of about 31% that is complete by 435 K is consistent with loss of 12 molecules of water per formula unit. Subsequent decomposition of the anhydrous material, as indicated by renewed mass loss (~29%), begins at roughly 805 K.

[Ni(H2O)4 (H2NC10H6 SO3)2] ⋅ 2H2O

This compound was prepared according to the same procedure as the Mn compound, using 1.503 g (6.7 mmol) of 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonic acid and 0.375 g (3.2 mmol) of nickel(II) carbonate (Baker Analyzed Reagent). An average of 1.58 g of dark purple diamond-shaped plates were collected for an 82% yield based on Ni. The TGA of these crystals showed a continuous mass loss of ~19% complete by 392 K. This mass loss is slightly above the 17.7% loss expected for six molecules of H2O and is most likely due to some additional hydration of the crystals that may have occurred on standing. The similarity in crystal morphology to the Mg, Mn, and Co compounds suggests that the Ni compound should be isomorphous, however the color (purple) is consistent with the coordination environment of the Ni as determined by the X-ray analysis. As for the other compounds in this series, the anhydrous metal sulfonate shows good thermal stability and does not begin to decompose to volatile products until about 810 K.

[Ag (H2O)2 (H3NC10H5 (SO3)2)] ⋅ 0.42H2O

A 1.504 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt (Eastman Organic Chemicals) and 1.464 g (8.6 mmol) of silver nitrate (Baker Analyzed Reagent) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting pale olive green solution was allowed to react for approximately 1 h, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Upon evaporation of most of the water, a thick mat of long pale yellow needle-shaped crystals was isolated from the bottom of the dish (average yield 2.27 g, >100% due to residual moisture in the product). TGA revealed a mass loss of approximately 7% complete by 375 K. This is somewhat less than the 9.6% expected based on the formula obtained from the X-ray structure. Given that the water of crystallization in this compound is present at partial occupancy, it is possible that the low water count obtained from the TGA is due to loss of water from the crystals prior to analysis. If only the coordinated water were retained in the structure, the expected mass loss on dehydration would be 8.1%. The rest of the TGA shows that this compound is less thermally stable than the others, with a series of significant mass losses beginning at 485 K. Unlike the divalent sulfonates, essentially the entire mass of the silver compound is ultimately volatilized by ~890 K.

[Ni (H2O)4 (H3NC10H5 (SO3)2)2]⋅ 4H2O

A 1.500 g (4.3 mmol) sample of 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonic acid disodium salt and 1.255 g (4.3 mmol) of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Aldrich) were dissolved together in approximately 50 mL of de-ionized water. The resulting green solution was stirred for 20 min, gravity-filtered into an evaporation dish, and set out at room temperature. Evaporation of the water yielded many long green needles of the product (average yield 0.86 g, 25%), which were recovered manually from the polycrystalline residue. TGA showed a ~20% mass loss complete by 490 K that is somewhat higher than the 17.9% expected for loss of eight water molecules per formula unit. This discrepancy could be due to residual moisture in the sample. The dehydrated material is stable up to 630 K, where a large (~35%) mass loss begins. Thus, both salts of the 6-aminonaphthalene-1,3-disulfonate are less thermally stable than the salts of the 5-aminonaphthalene-2-sulfonate.
